text:
In this video, you’ll see how 
to track resource compliance
using compliance scores in AWS Config.

This enhancement to AWS Config 
conformance packs saves time by

automating compliance management, 
increases visibility of risk controls,

and helps you manage risk through 
alignment with industry standards and regulations.

Using compliance scores, you 
can track remediation progress,

perform comparisons across 
different sets of requirements,

and see the impact of a specific 
change on your compliance posture.

We’ll begin on the main Conformance 
packs page in the AWS Config console.

A conformance pack is a collection 
of AWS Config rules and remediation

actions that can be easily 
deployed as a single entity.

AWS Config now supports compliance scores 
as an enhancement to conformance packs.

A compliance score is calculated 
based on the number of rule-to-resource

combinations that are compliant 
within the scope of a conformance pack.

Let’s drill down into a 
conformance pack to view its rules.

In this case, a number of 
rules are noncompliant.

Compliance scores are 
recalculated periodically.
This score was last updated 9 hours ago.

The compliance score timeline 
provides a visual representation
of any changes over time.
In this case, compliance has been steady.

The timeline is useful for detecting 
a noncompliant workload or even

malicious activity that would not 
have been apparent from looking
at a compliance score alone.

Conversely, the timeline will 
show when scores improve as
noncompliant rules are remediated.

The timeline is powered by Amazon 
CloudWatch metrics, so we have the
option to set alarms and thresholds.
Let’s go to the AWS Config dashboard.

A new widget displays compliance 
scores for all deployed conformance

packs, allowing for easy 
comparison across rule sets.

The lowest scores are listed first to highlight 
conformance packs that may need attention.

You’ve just seen how to track 
resource compliance using
compliance scores in AWS Config.

You can learn more about this topic in 
the description and links for this video.
Thanks for watching. Now it's your turn to try.
